article.headline: FedEx standout quarter in âtough conditionsâ boost stock to best gain since 1986
article.body: Wall Street heaped praise and a stock-rating upgrade on FedEx Corp. on Wednesday, after the delivery and logistics company surprised investors with a better-than-expected quarter despite the drying out of its more profitable business deliveries business amid the coronavirus pandemic. Shares of FedEx FDX, +0.18% Â rallied more than 14% on Wednesday, putting them on track for their best one-day percentage gain since September 1986, when the company shed its ZapMail faxing service after losing millions with the venture. A close around current levels would be the highest in six months. FedEx late Tuesday reported a fiscal fourth-quarter adjusted profit of $2.53 a share on sales of $17.4 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected FedEx to report adjusted earnings of $1.58 a share on sales of $16.4 billion. Going in, Wall Street was worried business-to-consumer deliveries wouldnât be enough to make up for the halt in business-to-business deliveries, which are more profitable and were plentiful before worldwide shutdowns related to the pandemic. The quarter was âseverely affectedâ by the COVID-19 pandemic, the company said, but the surge in business-to-consumer deliveries, with tweaks to improve profit margins, offset higher costs and other pandemic-related headwinds. Volumes for its FedEx Ground business grew 25% year-over-year. Analysts at J.P. Morgan, led by Brian Ossenbeck, raised their rating on FedEx stock to their equivalent of buy, pinning the upgrade on the âsolid EPS beat in tough conditions.â FedEx Ground enjoyed better margins and the Express service weathered the collapse in business-to-business deliveries better than anticipated, the analysts said in a note Wednesday. Fiscal 2020 may be a âthrowawayâ year but FedEx is reaping the benefits of having invested in improvements with the Ground business, analysts with Raymond James said in their note. FedEx âwill weather the (admittedly) severe impacts from the coronavirus (and) we see limited further downside at current levels, though we are keeping a close eye on the macro,â the Raymond James analysts said. The better margins for FedEx Ground were at the core of the quarterly beat, alongside resurfacing demand from Asia, Helane Becker at Cowen said. âAccelerating macro trends are working in FedExâs favor, though uncertainty looms with the overall economy,â she said. UBS analysts lifted their price target on FedEx to $181, from $158, implying a 29% upside for the shares. Fourth-quarter expectations were a âlow barâ to clear as estimates were falling in recent weeks and investors had low expectations for the quarter, but FedEx cleared it and in the process showed Wall Street âthe spread in profitability between their B2C and B2B business is likely not as wide as perceived.â Shares of FedEx have gained 5% year to date, contrasting with a loss of around 4% for the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â and the Dow Jones Industrial Averageâs DJIA, +0.56% decline of about 9%.
